title: Registered nurse - degree (NMC 2010)
change: End-point assessment plan revised. Funding band revision published 19 August 2021.
overviewOfRole: Giving care, advice and support to sick, injured or disabled people.
ssa2: 1.2 Nursing, and subjects and vocations allied to medicine
occupationalSummary: A career in nursing is dynamic and exciting with opportunities to work in a range of different roles as a Registered Nurse. Your nursing career will mean working with a variety of service users, families and carers, and with a range of health and care professionals and other agencies. You might be working in: a hospital, someone’s home, the community, social care or public health. Registered nurses are a key part of the multidisciplinary teams that meet the health and care needs of patients and service users. You will be at the centre of teams that can include other health and social care professionals. The current Nursing and Midwifery Council (NMC) standards comprise a common core of skills and knowledge for all nursing students, with specialisms in adult nursing, children’s nursing, mental health and learning disabilities.

knowledges.detail: How to act as a change agent and provide leadership through quality improvement and service development
How to systematically evaluate care and ensure you use the findings to improve people’s experience and care outcomes
How to identify priorities and manage time and resources effectively
How your own values, principles and assumptions may affect your practice.
How to take the lead in coordinating, delegating and supervising care safely and managing risk either working independently or as part of a team
How to work effectively across professional and agency boundaries
When and how to communicate with a and refer to other professionals and agencies respecting the choices of service users and others
The Code: Professional standards of practice and behaviour for nurses and midwives (NMC 2015), current legislation and other ethical and legal frameworks
How to practice in a holistic, non-judgemental, caring and sensitive manner
How to manage risk and promote health and well-being while aiming to empower choices that promote self-care and safety
The various roles, responsibilities and functions of the nurse and how to adapt your practice to meet the changing needs of people using the service
The roles and responsibilities of other health and social care professionals
How to keep your knowledge and skills up to date through continuing professional development
How to recognise the limits of your own competence and knowledge and where to seek advice or refer to other professionals
The value of evidence in practice and how to critically appraise research, apply relevant theory and research to your work and how to identify areas for further investigation
How to use appropriate diagnostic and decision making skills to assess, plan, deliver and evaluate care, communicate findings, influence change and promote health and best practice.
The structure and function of the human body and how other life, behavioural and social sciences apply to health, ill health, disability, ageing and death
Common physical and mental health problems and treatments

How behaviour, culture, socioeconomic and other factors, in the care environment and its location, can effect health, illness, health outcomes and public health priorities and take this into account when planning and delivering care
How to build partnerships and therapeutic relationships through safe, effective and non- discriminatory communication, taking account of individual differences, capabilities and needs
How to use communication skills and technologies to support person centred care and enhance quality and safety
How to use therapeutic principles to promote wellbeing, manage personal safety and resolve conflict

O1:Current legislation as it applies to all service users including protection of vulnerable adults and those with complex needs arising from ageing, cognitive impairment, long term conditions and those approaching the end of life. This legislation would cover areas such as safeguarding, equality and diversity, handling information and data protection
O1:Models of inter-professional care and the role of specialist teams
O1:Your leadership role in disaster management, major incidents and public health emergencies and respond appropriately according to your level of competence
O1:Theories and models of nursing assessment
O1:Early signs of illness in people of all ages
O1:How to recognise and manage an individual who is clinically deteriorating
O1:Theories and concepts of medical and surgical nursing
O1:How treatment goals and service user choices may change at different stages of progressive illness, loss and bereavement
O1:The range of invasive and non-invasive procedures, medical devices and current technological and pharmacological interventions

O1:How to work in partnership with people who have long term conditions that require medical or surgical nursing, and their families and carers, to provide therapeutic nursing interventions, optimise health and wellbeing, facilitate choice and maximise self-care and self-management
O1:Normal physiological and psychological processes of pregnancy and childbirth
O1:The signs and symptoms of anxiety or distress
O1:Common long-term conditions
O1:How to promote self-care to people with acute of long-term conditions
O1:The theories and concepts that underpin self-care
O2:Your role as an advocate for children, young people and their families, and working in partnership with them.
O2:The laws relating to child and parental consent, including giving and refusing consent, withdrawal of treatment and legal capacity
O2:That all children and young people have the right to be safe, enjoy life and reach their potential.
O2:The parent’s or carers primary role in achieving and maintaining the child or young person’s health and wellbeing
O2:Health and social care policies relating to the health and wellbeing of children and young people
O2:The role of other agencies and services in providing services to children and young people
O2:How to empower and enable children, young people, parents and carers to influence quality of care and influence the development of policies and strategies
O2:Where and when to seek extra help or advice to manage situations safely
O2:The range of issues that may arise during transition from children’s to adult services and how to respond to these
O2:Biological, psychological and social factors throughout infancy, childhood and adolescence
O2:Pharmacology, anatomy and physiology, pathology, psychology and sociology, from infancy to young adulthood
O2:Recognised, evidence based, child-centred frameworks
O2:The vulnerability and how to recognise the rapid physiological deterioration of infants and young people
O2:The central role of the nurse in preventing maltreatment, and safeguarding children and young people.
O2:When and how to identify and refer those at risk of experiencing harm
O2:The particular vulnerability of infants and young people in relation to accurate medicines administration
O2:Types of negotiation skills
O2:How to take account of each child and young person’s individuality, including their stage of development, ability to understand, culture, learning or communication difficulties and health status
O2: All aspects of development from infancy to young adulthood, and identify each child or young person’s developmental stage, in order to communicate effectively with them.
O2:How to use play, distraction and communication tools in the nursing care of children

O3:How current legislation applies to all service users, paying special attention to the protection of vulnerable people, including those with complex needs arising from aging, cognitive impairment, long term conditions and those approaching end of life
O3: Understand how to exercise professional advocacy, and know when it is appropriate to refer to independent advocacy services to safeguard dignity and human rights
O3:That people with learning disabilities are full and equal citizens
O3:The collaborative management, delegation and supervision skills used to create, manage and support therapeutic environments for people with learning disabilities
O3:How people with learning disabilities receive support to addresses their physical, social, economic, psychological, spiritual and other needs when assessing, planning and delivering care
O3:Your unique contribution is recognised in service design and provision
O3:The health and developmental needs of all people with learning disabilities, and the factors that might influence them.
O3:The impact of different forms of learning disability on capacity to make health related decisions and self-manage care
O3:The range of essential and complex physical and mental health needs that can be experienced by people with learning disabilities
O3:How to recognise the range of needs that people in your care may experience
O3:Models and theories of person centred approaches to assessment of people with learning disabilities
O3:How to work in partnership to agree and implement individual care plans and ensure continuity of care
O3:How to implement and review plans that promote optimum health and wellbeing and facilitate equal access to all health, social acre and specialist services for people with learning disabilities
O3:How to facilitate choice and maximise self-care and self-management and co- ordinate the transition between f services and agencies
O3:How to communicate and negotiate effectively with other professionals, services and agencies.
O3:The range of person centred alternative and augmentative communication strategies and skills
O3:How to make relevant information accessible and understandable to people with learning disabilities
O3:The structured approaches to assessment and communication with people with a learning disability who have complex physical and psychological health needs or those in behavioural distress
O3:How to recognise and respond to complex behaviour that may be used as a means of communication by people with learning disabilities

O4:How current legislation applies to all service users, paying special attention to the protection of vulnerable people, including those with complex needs arising from aging, cognitive impairment, long term conditions and those approaching end of life
O4:Mental health legislation and how it relates to care and treatment of people with mental health problems
O4:The inequalities and discrimination that may arise from or contribute to mental health problems
O4:The value of your own mental health and wellbeing.
O4:How personal values, beliefs and emotions impact on practice, and how your own practice aligns with mental health legislation, policies and values based frameworks
O4:How working in mental health can have an emotional impact on self
O4:How to reflect on practice and engage in supervision
O4:How your values, beliefs and emotions affect your leadership
O4:How to shape future services, aid recovery and challenge discrimination and inequality
O4:Models of clinical supervision within values based frameworks
O4:Theories and models of best practice in mental health care and treatment
O4:How to enhance safety, psychological security and therapeutic outcomes
O4:Positive risk management and how to ensure continuity of care across service boundaries
O4:Range of evidence based individual and group psychological and psychosocial interventions to carry out systematic needs assessments, develop case formulations and negotiate goals
O4:Range of evidence based individual and group psychological and psychosocial interventions to develop and implement care plans and evaluate outcomes in partnership with service users and others.
O4:The benefits and unwanted effects of pharmacological and physical treatments and the range of choices and alternatives
O4:How to recognise the health and social factors that can contribute to crisis and relapse management in a way that ensures safety and security and promotes recovery
O4:Evidence based models of risk assessment, suicide prevention, intervention and self-harm reduction
O4:Positive risk-taking and how to ensure that this is balanced with the need for safety
O4:The therapeutic use of self
O4:Principles and theories of therapeutic relationships
O4:How to use interpersonal approaches and skills to help people explore and make sense of their experiences in a way to promote recovery
O4:Signs and symptoms that may be experienced by those with mental health problems
O4:How to facilitate therapeutic groups for people experiencing mental health problems and their families and carers
O4:How abuse and trauma impact on people’s wellbeing and the development of mental health problems
O4:Reflect on your own mental health and know when to share aspects of your own experience to inspire hope while maintaining profession boundaries

behaviours.detail: You will treat people with dignity, respecting individual's diversity, beliefs, culture, needs, values, privacy and preferences. You will show respect and empathy for those you work with, have the courage to challenge areas of concern and work to evidence based best practice. You will also be adaptable, reliable and consistent, show discretion, resilience and self-awareness and demonstrate leadership

skills.detail: Be professionally accountable and use clinical governance processes to maintain and improve nursing practice and standards of healthcare.
Respond autonomously and confidently to planned and uncertain situations, managing yourself and others effectively
Create and maximise opportunities to improve services and demonstrate the potential to develop further management and leadership skills
Act first and foremost to care for and safeguard the public.
Practice autonomously within your scope of practice and be responsible and accountable for safe, compassionate, person centred, evidence based nursing that respects and maintains human rights.
Show professionalism and integrity and work within recognised professional, ethical and legal frameworks.

Work in partnership with other health and social care professionals and agencies, service users, their carers and families in all settings, including the community, ensuring that decisions about care are shared
Practice autonomously, compassionately, skilfully and safely, and must maintain dignity and promote wellbeing.
Assess and meet the full range of essential physical and mental health needs of people of all ages
Meet the more complex and coexisting needs of people in any setting
Make shared decisions with service users
Communicate in a safe, effective, compassionate and respectful way
Communicate effectively using a wide range of strategies and interventions
Work with service users and others to obtain information needed to make reasonable adjustments that promote optimum health and enable equal access to services
O1:Promote the rights, choices and wishes of all adults and, where appropriate, children and young people, paying particular attention to equality and diversity and the needs of an aging population
O1:Work in partnership to address people’s needs in all healthcare settings

O1:Apply current legislation to all service users especially the protection of vulnerable people, including those with complex needs arising from ageing, cognitive impairment, long-term conditions and those approaching the end of life
O1:Provide leadership in managing adult nursing care, understand and coordinate inter-professional care when needed, and liaise with specialist teams
O1:Take the lead in responding to the needs of people of all ages in a variety of circumstances including situations where immediate or urgent care is needed
O1:Make accurate assessments and start appropriate and timely management of those that are acutely ill, at risk of clinical deterioration, or require emergency care
O1:Deliver medical and surgical nursing interventions to respond to adult’s full range of health and dependency needs
O1:Recognise and respond to the changing needs of adults, families and carers during terminal illness.
O1:Safely use invasive and non-invasive procedures, medical devises, and current technological and pharmacological interventions

O1:Work in partnership with people who have long term conditions that require medical or surgical nursing, and their families and carers, to provide therapeutic nursing interventions, optimise health and wellbeing, facilitate choice and maximise self-care and self-management
O1:Work with the midwife and other professionals and agencies to provide basic nursing care to pregnant women and families during pregnancy and after childbirth.
O1:Respond safely and effectively to an emergency to safeguard the health of mother and baby
O1:Listen with empathy and respond empathetically and positively to people of all ages who may be anxious, distressed or facing problems with their health and wellbeing
O1:Promote the concept, knowledge and practice of self-care with people with acute and long term conditions using a range of communication skills and strategies
O2:Deliver child and family centred care; empower children and young people to express their views and preferences; and maintain and recognise their rights and best interests
O2:Recognise, respect and respond to the individuality of every child and young person
O2:Act as an advocate for the right of all children and young people to lead full and independent lives
O2:Work in partnership with children, young people and their families to negotiate, plan and deliver child and family centred care, education and support
O2:Offer advice and support on parenting in health and illness
O2:Listen and respond to the wishes of children and young people and influence the delivery of health and social care of children and young people.
O2:Work with other agencies and services ensure seamless and well supported transition to adult services
O2:Empower and enable children, young people, parents and carers to influence the quality of care and develop future policies and strategies
O2:Ensure that wherever possible care is delivered in the child or young person’s home, or in another environment that suits their age, needs and preferences
O2:Use effective clinical decision making skills when managing complex and unpredictable situations, especially where the views of children or young people and their parents and carers differ

O2:Work effectively with young people who have continuing health needs, their families, the multidisciplinary team and other agencies to manage effective transition from children’s to adult services, taking account of individual needs and preferences
O2:Care safely and effectively for children and young people in all settings, and safeguard them.
O2:Deliver care to meet essential and complex physical and mental health needs
O2:Use recognised, evidence based, child-centred frameworks to assess, plan, implement, evaluate and record care, and to underpin clinical judgements and decision making
O2:Carry out comprehensive nursing assessments of children and young people, recognising the particular vulnerability of infants and young children to rapid physiological deterioration

O2: Include health promotion, and illness and injury prevention in nursing practice. Promote early intervention to address the links between early life adversity and adult ill health, and the risks to current and future physical, mental, emotional and sexual health of children and young people

O2:Use numeracy skills for medicines management , assessment, measuring, monitoring and recording which recognise the particular vulnerability of infants and young people in relation to accurate medicines calculation
O2:Use negotiation skills to ensure the best interests of children and young people in all decisions including the continuation or withdrawal of care.
O2:Communicate effectively with children, their parents and carers

O2:Work with the child, young person and others to ensure they are actively involved in decision making, in order to maintain independence and take account of their ongoing intellectual, physical and emotional needs
O2:Use play, distraction and communication tools appropriate to the child’s or young person’s stage of development including those  with sensory or cognitive impairment
O2:Ensure that where possible children and young people understand their healthcare needs and can make or contribute to informed choices about aspects of their care

O3:Promote the individuality, independence, rights, choice and social inclusion of people with learning disabilities and highlight their strengths and abilities at all times whilst encouraging others to do the same
O3:Facilitate the active participation of families and carers

O3:Promote the autonomy, rights and choices of people with learning disabilities and support and involve their families and carers, ensuring that each person’s rights are upheld according to policy and the law
O3:Promote the health and wellbeing of people with learning disabilities by focusing on and developing strengths and abilities to enable inclusive lifestyles
O3:Exercise collaborative management, delegation and supervision skills to create, manage and support therapeutic environments for people with learning disabilities

O3:Take the lead in ensuring people with learning disabilities receive support that addresses their physical, social, economic, psychological, spiritual and other needs when assessing, planning and delivering care
O3:Provide direction through leadership and education to ensure that your unique contribution is recognised in service design and provision
O3:Improve and maintain the health and independence of people of all ages with learning disabilities through skilled direct and indirect nursing care.
O3:Provide direct care to meet the essential and complex physical and mental health needs of people with learning disabilities
O3:Recognise and respond to the needs of all people who come into your care

O3:Use structured, person-centred approaches to assess, interpret and respond therapeutically to people with learning disabilities, and their often complex, pre-existing physical and psychological health needs.
O3:Work in partnership with service users, carers and other professionals, services and agencies to agree and implement individual care plans and ensure continuity of care

O3:Lead the development, implementation and review of individual plans for all people with learning disabilities, to promote their optimum health and wellbeing and facilitate their equal access to all health, social care and specialist services

O3:Work in partnership with people with learning disabilities and their families and carers to facilitate choice and maximise self-care and self-management and co-ordinate the transition between different services and agencies
O3:Use sophisticated communication and interpersonal skills and strategies to work with people of all ages who have learning disabilities and help them to express themselves
O3:Ensure people with learning disabilities and their families and carers, are fully involved in decision making
O3:Use the full range of person-centred alternative and augmentative communication strategies and skills to build partnerships and therapeutic relationships with people with learning disabilities
O3:Make relevant information accessible to and understandable by people with learning disabilities, including adaptation of format, presentation and delivery

O3:Use a structured approach to assess, communicate with, interpret and respond therapeutically to people with learning disability who have complex physical and psychological health needs or those in behavioural distress
O3:Recognise and respond therapeutically to complex behaviour that people with learning disability may use as a means of communication

O4:Work with people of all ages using values based mental health frameworks, using different methods of engaging people and work in a way that promotes positive relationships focussed on social inclusion, human rights and recovery, that is, a person’s ability to live a self-directed life, with or without symptoms, that they believe is meaningful and satisfying

O4:Address the potential power imbalances between professionals and people experiencing mental health problems, including situations where compulsory measures are used, by helping people exercise their rights, upholding safeguards and ensuring minimal restrictions on their lives
O4:Promote mental health and wellbeing, while challenging the inequalities and discrimination that may arise from or contribute to mental health problems
O4:Engage in reflection and supervision to explore the emotional impact on self of working in mental health

O4:Contribute to the leadership, management and design of mental health services and work with service users, carers and other professionals and agencies to shape future services, aid recovery and challenge discrimination and inequality
O4:Promote and participate in clinical supervision and reflection, within a values based framework
O4:Raise awareness of mental health, and provide advice and support in best practice in mental health care and treatment

O4:Contribute to the management of mental health care environments by giving priority to actions that enhance peoples safety, psychological security and therapeutic outcomes, and by ensuring effective communication, positive risk management and continuity of care across service boundaries

O4:Use a range of evidence-based psychological, psychosocial and other complex therapeutic skills and interventions to provide person centred care and support across all ages, in a way that promotes self-determination and aids recovery.

O4:Promote improvements to in physical and mental health and wellbeing and provide direct care to meet both the essential and complex physical and mental health needs of people with mental health problems
O4:Promote mental health, help prevent mental health problems in at risk groups, and enhance the health and wellbeing of people with mental health problems

O4:Help people experiencing mental health problems to make informed choices about pharmacological and physical treatments by providing education and information on the benefits and unwanted effects, choices and alternatives. Support people to identify actions that promote health and help to balance the benefits and unwanted effects
O4:Provide support and therapeutic interventions for people experiencing acute mental health problems
O4:Work positively and proactively with people who are at risk of suicide or self-harm, and use evidence-based models of suicide prevention, intervention and harm reduction to minimise risk
O4:Promote the self-determination and expertise of people with mental health problems, using a range of approaches, using a range of approaches and tools
O4:Maximise service user involvement and therapeutic engagement, using interventions that balance the need for safety with positive risk-taking
O4:Practice in a way that focuses on the therapeutic use of self
O4:Draw on a range of methods of engaging with people of all ages experiencing mental health problems, and those important to them, to develop and maintain therapeutic relationships
O4:Work alongside people, using a range of interpersonal approaches and skills to help them explore and make sense of their experiences in a way that promotes recovery
O4:Use skills of relationship building and communication to engage with and support people distressed by hearing voices, experiencing distressing thoughts or experiencing other  perceptual problems
O4:Facilitate therapeutic groups with people experiencing mental health problems and their families and carers
O4:Use interpersonal skills and interventions that help people disclose and discuss their experiences as part of their recovery
O4:Use your personal qualities, experiences and interpersonal skills to develop and maintain therapeutic, recovery focussed relationships with people and therapeutic groups

O4:Foster helpful and enabling relationships with families, carers and others using communication skills that enable psychosocial education, problem solving and other interventions to help people cope and to safeguard those who are vulnerable
